subject: Re: Best Practice for Tests ?

messageBody:
I've used both the seperate directory approach and same directory
approach. Both worked fine, so use which ever you like.

My preference is to put the test in the same directory as the class.
I like this because it reduces the number of clicks I have to make in
my IDE (JBuilder) to get from production class to test class. When
you are developing in a test-first fashion, you will frequently
switch between the test code and the production code. By putting
them in the same directory this makes it easier to navigate in the
IDE. Yes, this mixes production and test files together. However it
is very easy to seperate them in a build script (if you use a simple
naming convention for test files). Since you will spend more of your
work day navigating between source files than seperating out test
code, I chose to optimize the # of clicks I had to make in the IDE by
putting files in the same directory.

I use the following naming convention:
Someclass.java
SomeclassT.java // the unit test
SomeclassM.java // a mock object of Someclass

- Greg
